concepts.title: Average (Mean)
concepts.content: The average (or mean) gives a single representative value for a set of data. Average = Sum of all scores √∑ Total number of scores. For example, if Asmita cycles in 20, 20, 22, 18, 18, 20 minutes, the average = 118/6 = 19‚Öî minutes. The average can be a fraction even when all scores are whole numbers.

examples.text: Average can be a fraction even if all scores are whole numbers

keyPoints: Average = Sum of all scores √∑ Number of scores
Also called 'mean'
Average can be a decimal/fraction even for whole-number data
Gives a central representative value for the data
Convert all values to same units before finding average
concepts.funFact: üåæ A farmer says 'average yield per acre' ‚Äî this single number represents production across all acres!

concepts.title: Calculating Average ‚Äî Worked Examples
concepts.content: Steps to find average: 1) Express all values in the same unit. 2) Add all scores. 3) Divide by the count. Example: distances 950m, 800m, 700m, 1.5km, 1km, 750m ‚Äî convert 1.5km=1500m, 1km=1000m first, then sum and divide by 6.

examples.text: Mix of km and m: convert all to same unit first

keyPoints: Always convert to same units before averaging
Sum all values then divide by count
Check: average should lie between min and max
Used in weather, agriculture, economics
Average of same numbers = that number itself
concepts.funFact: ‚òî Average rainfall decides if a region is 'arid', 'semi-arid' or 'rainy' ‚Äî used in classifying India's climate zones!

concepts.title: Frequency
concepts.content: When a score appears more than once in data, the number of times it appears is called its frequency. Instead of listing every occurrence, we record scores and their frequencies in a table ‚Äî much more efficient for large datasets.

examples.text: Priya shelling peas: 50 pods, frequencies of 2,3,4,5,6,7,8 peas per pod
Dice: numbers 1-6, frequency of each number in 40 rolls

keyPoints: Frequency = number of times a score occurs
Same score can appear multiple times
Frequency table saves space for large datasets
Total of all frequencies = N (total count)
Finding average from frequency table is more efficient
concepts.funFact: üìä In a class of 40 students, instead of writing 40 heights, a frequency table shows each height once with how many students have it!

concepts.title: Frequency Distribution Table
concepts.content: A frequency table has three columns: Score, Tally marks, Frequency. Scores are written in ascending order. Tally marks are made one by one (groups of 5: four vertical, fifth diagonal). Count tallies to get frequency. Sum of all frequencies = N (total number of scores).

examples.text: Distance data: score 4 has frequency 5 (appears 5 times)
Pea pods: frequencies of 8,15,12,2,7,3,3 for 2,3,4,5,6,7,8 peas; N=50

keyPoints: Three columns: Score | Tally marks | Frequency
Scores written in ascending order
5th tally mark crosses the previous 4 (easier counting)
Cross off each data item as you count it
Sum of all frequencies = N = total number of data
concepts.funFact: üñäÔ∏è Tally marks (groups of 5) were used by ancient humans long before writing systems ‚Äî it's one of humanity's oldest counting methods!

concepts.title: Average from Frequency Table
concepts.content: For large datasets, use the frequency table to find average efficiently. Instead of adding all 50 values individually, multiply each score by its frequency: sum(score √ó frequency) / N. Example: 8 pods with 2 peas: 2√ó8=16; 15 pods with 3 peas: 3√ó15=45; etc.

examples.text: Much faster than adding 50 individual numbers!
N = total frequency = sum of all individual frequencies

keyPoints: Average = Œ£(score √ó frequency) / N
More efficient than adding all values individually
Multiply each score by its frequency first
Sum all products, then divide by N
Average may be a decimal even for whole-number scores
concepts.funFact: üå± Priya's mother used this method to find average peas per pod without adding 50 numbers! Seven multiplications vs fifty additions.

keyConcepts: Average (mean) = Sum of all scores √∑ Number of scores
Average can be a fraction even when all scores are whole numbers
Frequency = number of times a score appears in data
Frequency table: Score | Tally marks | Frequency
Tally marks: groups of 5 (four vertical, fifth diagonal)
Sum of all frequencies = N (total data count)
Average from frequency table = Œ£(score √ó frequency) / N
commonMisconceptions: Average must be a whole number ‚Äî FALSE, it can be a decimal
Average = middle value (median) ‚Äî FALSE, average is sum divided by count
Frequency = tally marks ‚Äî PARTLY TRUE, frequency is the count shown by tally marks
You need to list all data to find average ‚Äî FALSE, use score √ó frequency for efficiency
